Message.Title: Princeton professor says BO lied about Romney tax plan study
Message.Msg: Princeton professor said the Obama campaign is misrepresenting his work and that Mitt Romney’s tax plan does not require raising taxes on the lower and middle class as Obama claimed. “I can’t tell exactly how the Obama campaign reached that characterization of my work,” Rosen said Professor Rosen's objection follows a similar statement released by the AARP immediately after the Oct. 3rd debate. Senior Vice President John Hishta said, "America's voters deserve more than talking points" and “AARP has never consented to the use of its name by the Obama campaign."

Message.Title: Major Restaurant Chain Cuts Hours to Avoid Obamacare Costs
Message.Msg: A major restaurant group is cutting its employees hours in the hopes of cutting the costs of healthcare. Darden Restaurants, which owns the Red Lobster, Olive Garden, LongHorn Steakhouse, and Yard House chains has stopped offering full-time schedules to hourly workers, the Orlando Sentinel reports. The company plans to offer a maximum of 28 hours per week per employee. Under a section of President Barack Obama's Affordable Healthcare Act, large employers face fines of up to $3,000 per employee if they fail to provide insurance for employees who work an average of 30 or more hours per week. Darden said it offers health insurance to its 185,000 employees nationwide but many are on a limited-benefit plan which will be phased out under Obamacare.

Message.Title: winholders Creationist Hallelujah moment...
Message.Msg: ...so excited, he choked the rattlesnake. To my post: “Broun also said that he believes the Earth is about 9,000 years old and that it was made in six days. He sits on the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology.” winholder replied: “You can post this kind of crap and try to paint all Republicans as being the same if you want…” Winjondandale, don’t you ever get tired of just making stuff up to suit your perverted views? Show me where I even mentioned other Republicans. You can’t, because I didn’t. I posted a few sentences verbatim about a Congressman from Georgia who disavows science in general, and brazenly states unequivocally that everything he “was taught about evolution and embryology and Big Bang theory, all that is lies straight from the pit of hell.” And, as stated, “he believes the Earth is about 9,000 years old and that it was made in six days.” This clown, who unbelievably is also a doctor, even more surprisingly sits on The House Committee on Science, Space and Technology…and, yes, he happens to be a Republican. I made no mention of any other Republicans, and, quite frankly, if he was a Democrat or an Independent I would still choose to have him removed from that Committee. The point wasn’t at all about politics…it was about ignorance and blind-faith stupidity. And it was about how the lack of education by the electorate permits fundamentalist crackpots to be put in positions of authority, not unlike in some third-world countries now promoting Sharia law. And it was about the importance of the Constitutional concept of the First Amendment, summarized by Justice Hugo Black in 1947, when he said, “In the words of Thomas Jefferson, the clause against establishment of religion by law was intended to erect a wall of separation between church and state.” However, now that you’ve chosen, as you usually do, to confuse the issue for your own version of truth, let’s examine your points. Yes, he’s a Republican. You wanted to drag the women politicians from California into this, for reasons unknown. But go ahead, if you will. Name me any other politicians from the Democratic side who would suggest that the earth is only 9000 years old. While you’re at it, how old do you think the earth is, winny? Do you agree with this guy, or not? If you don’t, why are you defending him? Oh, that’s right, global warming and evolution are simply liberal conspiracies designed to help an illegal alien President to take over America. Here, you’re the smart guy…please debate Dr. Williams, if you’d care to (which I seriously doubt – these are scientists – you’re some home schooled message board dipstick.) “The simple fact is, Creationists have NO evidence that points to a 6 - 10 thousand year age for the earth! This belief is an article of faith for creationists and they have never found any significant scientific data to back it up. Finally, I would like to raise the issue of motive in these questions of the age of the earth. Scientists have no reason to claim an age of the earth of 4.5 billion years except for the results of decades of research and thousands of tests by independent researchers indicating the effectiveness of radiometric dating and that 4.5 billion years is the correct age of the earth. They have no stake in this date - other than that the facts support it. As the geochronologist Dalrymple said, ‘I have no reason whatsoever to want the age of the earth to be any more or less than it happens to be. I would take great delight in proving that the earth is only 10,000 years old if it were possible to do so.’ Creationists, on the other hand, have an extreme interest in proving the age of the earth to be 6 - 10 thousand years - it is required by their fundamentalist (literal) Biblical theology. To them, the earth must have been created in six literal days six thousand years ago. Any other possibility is a violation of their deeply held religious beliefs. In fact, all of the creation ‘science’ organizations require members to adhere to clearly religious ‘creeds’ that require them to accept the authority of the Bible in all matters. While this may be good religion, it is very, very bad science! Can we really trust such people to make a fair and unbiased attempt to determine the true age of the earth? We certainly haven't seen any evidence of it so far.” – Dr. Robert Williams And one last point. Here’s what you’re promoting. On a recent broadcast of “The Newsroom” on HBO, head writer, Aaron Sorkin, compiled a terrifying list of the belief system of a group we are currently battling in Afghanistan: “tribal mentality, ideological purity, unmoved by facts, hostile fear of progress, pathological hatred of the U.S. government, control of women’s bodies and choices, severe xenophobia, compromise is weakness, intolerance of dissent, demonization of education, denial of science, undeterred by new information, fundamentalist interpretation of scripture literalism, disallowance of voting for some sects of the population.” Gee, that sounds almost identical to the ideology of another such group a bit closer to home – The Tea Party, or as some refer to them, America’s Tal#iban. Before you folks do away with The Department of Education, I highly recommend that you go back to school and stop promoting ignorance.

Topic.Title: Princeton professor says BO lied about Romney tax plan study

Message.Msg: "Rosen's paper did find that families making more than $100,000 per year would have to pay $81 billion more in taxes under Romney's tax plan, a 12 percent increase. But his paper did not explicitly say whether these families, whose incomes he assumes would be rising, would actually pay a higher tax rate. Rosen's conclusion that Romney's tax plan is mathematically possible rests on a questionable assumption: namely that Romney's tax cuts for the rich would lead to robust economic growth. In fact, economic growth sharply slowed during the Bush administration, when President George W. Bush cut taxes for the rich. Brad DeLong, economics professor at the University of California at Berkeley, also notes that President Ronald Reagan's tax cuts for the rich did not lead to much stronger economic growth either."

Topic.Title: Princeton professor says BO lied about Romney tax plan study

Message.Msg: The main conclusion of the Rosen study is that under plausible assumptions, a proposal suggested by Governor Romney can be revenue neutral and keep the net tax burden on taxpayers about the same. That is, an increase in the tax burden on lower and middle income individuals is not required in order to make the overall plan revenue neutral.

Message.Msg: The Quote of the Decade: "The fact that we are here today to debate raising America's debt limit is a sign of leadership failure. It is a sign that the US Government cannot pay its own bills. It is a sign that we now depend on ongoing financial assistance from foreign countries to finance our Government's reckless fiscal policies. Increasing America 's debt weakens us domestically and internationally. Leadership means that, "the buck stops here.' Instead, Washington is shifting the burden of bad choices today onto the backs of our children and grandchildren. America has a debt problem and a failure of leadership. COSTELLO: You just said 9%. ABBOTT: 9% Unemployed. COSTELLO: Right 9% out of work. ABBOTT: No, that's 16%. COSTELLO: Okay, so it's 16% unemployed. ABBOTT: No, that's 9%. COSTELLO: WAIT A MINUTE. Is it 9% or16%? ABBOTT: 9% are unemployed. 16% are out of work. COSTELLO: IF you are out of work you are unemployed. ABBOTT: No, Obama said you can't count the "Out of Work" as the unemployed. You have to look for work to be unemployed. COSTELLO: BUT THEY ARE OUT OF WORK!!! ABBOTT: No, you miss his point. COSTELLO: What point? ABBOTT: Someone who doesn't look for work can't be counted with those who look for work. It wouldn't be fair. COSTELLO: To whom? ABBOTT: The unemployed. COSTELLO: But they are ALL out of work. ABBOTT: No, the unemployed are actively looking for work. Those who are out of work gave up looking and if you give up, you are no longer in the ranks of the unemployed. COSTELLO: So if you're off the unemployment roles that would count as less unemployment? ABBOTT: Unemployment would go down. Absolutely! COSTELLO: The unemployment just goes down because you don't look for work? ABBOTT: Absolutely it goes down. That's how Obama gets it to 9%. Otherwise it would be 16%. He doesn't want you to read about 16% unemployment. COSTELLO: That would be tough on his reelection. ABBOTT: Absolutely. COSTELLO: Wait, I got a question for you. That means there are two ways to bring down the unemployment number? ABBOTT: Two ways is correct. COSTELLO: Unemployment can go down if someone gets a job? ABBOTT: Correct. COSTELLO: And unemployment can also go down if you stop looking for a job? ABBOTT: Bingo. COSTELLO: So there are two ways to bring unemployment down, and the easier of the two is to have obama's supporters stop looking for work. ABBOTT: Now you're thinking like the Obama Economy Czar. COSTELLO: I don't even know what the hell I just said! ABBOTT: Now you're thinking like Obama.
